content: In the talk ((Co)algebraic analysis of social systems: from graphs to hypergraphs) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nnBg4haKyF0, Nina Otter mentioned about representing a directed graph G=(V,E⊆V×V)G=(V, E \subseteq V \times V)G=(V,E⊆V×V) as a coalgebra of the covariant power set endofunctor P ⁣:Set→SetP \colon Set \to SetP:Set→Set given by (V,NGo ⁣:V→P(V))(V, N^{o}_{G} \colon V \to P(V))(V,NGo​:V→P(V)), where NGoN^{o}_{G} NGo​ is the out neighbourhood function. However, I do not see a way to generalise this definition to multigraphs unless (we suitably talk about multisets). Are there any exisiting coalgebra formalisms for multigraphs? Or, am I misunderstanding something fundamentally?

There are! Ordinary directed multigraphs, i.e. parallel pairs E⇉V,E\rightrightarrows V,E⇉V, form a presheaf category, and all presheaf categories are comonadic over sets, with the forgetful functor given in this case by E(G)⊔V(G),E(G)\sqcup V(G),E(G)⊔V(G), the disjoint union of all the elements of the presheaf; the analogous formula works in general. But you mentioned multisets, so maybe this isn't quite the kind of multigraph you mean? Most possibilities are comonadic, if you'd like to pin one down.

Thanks!! Yes, I meant the ordinary directed multigraph G=(E⇉V)G=( E \rightrightarrows V)G=(E⇉V) only.

I wanted to see explicitly, whether it can be seen as function ϕ(G) ⁣:X→T(X) \phi (G)\colon X \to T(X)ϕ(G):X→T(X), for an endofunctor T ⁣:Set→SetT \colon Set \to SetT:Set→Set and a set XXX.

For a directed graph(not a multigraph) G′=(V′,E′⊆V′×V′)G'=(V', E' \subseteq V' \times V')G′=(V′,E′⊆V′×V′), Nina considered TTT as the covariant power set endofunctor P ⁣:Set→SetP \colon Set \to SetP:Set→Set, X=V′X=V'X=V′ and the ϕ(G′)\phi(G')ϕ(G′) is the out-neighbourhood function. The function ϕ(G′)\phi(G')ϕ(G′) completely determine G′G'G′.

Now, we are talking about the covariant presheaf G ⁣:Sch→SetG \colon Sch \to SetG:Sch→Set, where SchSchSch is the category freely generated on E⇉VE \rightrightarrows VE⇉V ( parallel pairs). Are you saying that for this covariant presheaf GGG , we have T=P ⁣:Set→SetT=P \colon Set \to SetT=P:Set→Set, X=G(V)⊔G(E)X= G(V) \sqcup G(E)X=G(V)⊔G(E) and a function ϕ(G) ⁣:G(V)⊔G(E)→P(G(V)⊔G(E))\phi(G) \colon G(V) \sqcup G(E) \to P(G(V) \sqcup G(E)) ϕ(G):G(V)⊔G(E)→P(G(V)⊔G(E)) [Need to define ϕ(G)\phi(G)ϕ(G)]

I am new to the formalism of graphs as coalgebras. So, I may sound naive. Sorry for that!

No, G(V)⊔G(E)G(V)\sqcup G(E)G(V)⊔G(E) is the left adjoint of the comonadic adjunction. The right adjoint sends a set XXX to the chaotic graph X3⇉XX^3\rightrightarrows XX3⇉X which has edges between each x1,x2x_1,x_2x1​,x2​ labeled by each x3∈X.x_3\in X.x3​∈X. Thus the comonad is carried by the composite endofunctor, X↦X+X3.X\mapsto X+X^3.X↦X+X3. A coalgebra structure X→X+X3X\to X+X^3X→X+X3 gives a decomposition of XXX into disjoint pieces that’ll correspond to vertices and edges, and the coalgebra axioms make sure every vertex is mapped to itself and every edge is mapped to itself as an edge between two vertices, producing a well defined graph.

So the powerset functor doesn’t appear here at all; you can’t describe a directed multigraph in terms of a vertex’s mere set of out-neighbors, nor does an edge have a mere set of adjacent vertices, so it has no role to play.

This is a special case of Ahman-Uustalu’s theorem that polynomial comonads are the same as small categories, which you can find explained in much more detail in David and Nelson Niu’s book on Poly, if you’re curious.

Another approach would be to use the multiset (or bag) functor B ⁣:Set→Set\mathcal{B}\colon Set \to Set B:Set→Set, acting like P\mathcal{P}P, but every element can be contained an arbitrary number of times in each subset, so BX\mathcal{B}XBX essentially consists of functions of type X→NX \to \mathbb{N}X→N. This is maybe a bit closer in spirit to what happens in the presentation, since this style of coalgebra does usually not involve comonads.

Though this does give you a different notion of graph homomorphism compared to presheaf graphs.

Thanks!! Yes, I agree. I think we may also think of B ⁣:Set→Set\mathcal{B} \colon Set \to SetB:Set→Set as the free commutative monoid monad i.e. B=U∘ϕ\mathcal{B}= U \circ \phiB=U∘ϕ, where ϕ ⁣:Set→CommMon\phi \colon Set \to CommMonϕ:Set→CommMon is the free commutative monoid functor (X↦N[X]X \mapsto \mathbb{N}[X]X↦N[X]) and U ⁣:CommMon→SetU \colon CommMon \to SetU:CommMon→Set is the forgetful functor, that takes a commutative monoid to its underlying set. Then, any graph G=[E⇉V]G=[E \rightrightarrows V]G=[E⇉V] can be described as the coalgebra V→NoU(N[V])V \xrightarrow{N^{o}} U(\mathbb{N}[V])VNo​U(N[V]), where the function NoN^{o}No takes a vertex vvv to the formal linear combination α1v1+…αnvn\alpha_1v_1 + \ldots \alpha_nv_nα1​v1​+…αn​vn​ , where α1\alpha_1α1​ is the number of edges from vvv to v1v_1v1​, α2\alpha_2α2​ is the number of edges from vvv to v2v_2v2​, and so on.

This is true-ish, but the categories are far from equivalent, since you can’t permute the edges between two vertices in the multiset picture. Instead a map just becomes a function on vertices which numerically preserves arities everywhere. This kind of graph is sometimes used, although the main near-example I’m aware of is in Petri nets, which are a touch more complicated.
Yep, and this already happens in the original example of P\mathcal{P}P-coalgebras. I would expect a graph homomorphism to preserve edges, but coalgebra homomorphisms preserve and reflect them.

Thanks. I also felt the presentation is "closer to Petri nets" , but I think for a Petri net T⇉N[E]T \rightrightarrows \mathbb{N}[E]T⇉N[E] over the set of entities EEE, we need a function f ⁣:T→U(N[E])×U(N[E])f \colon T \to U(\mathbb{N}[E]) \times U(\mathbb{N}[E])f:T→U(N[E])×U(N[E]) denoting its inputs and outputs. I am not able to guess at the moment how to see fff in the form of a colalgebra X→B(X)X \to \mathbb{B}(X)X→B(X) for some endofunctor B ⁣:Set→Set\mathbb{B} \colon Set \to SetB:Set→Set, so that coalgebra morphisms become the morphisms of Petri nets.
